reviews.review_msg: boring lectures, not engaging at all. the curve saved me

He is very unorganized and it is very boring. He seems to make up a lot of content on the spot and rambles about personal matters more than lecture content. He is also very unempathic and does not care to answer students questions or support their learning. DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS.
Rambles ALOT, lectures are super boring!

Very boring, non stop stuttering in lectures, barley knows anything about the course he is teaching. Unclear assignments, unclear deadlines, changes assignment instructions the day before they are due, changed course grading scheme multiple times throughout the semester. Assignments aren't too hard but not a good overall experience.

simon is super energetic and made my first ever business course super exciting! I highly recommend taking a course with him he is great. you will have weekly homework assignments and readings for tutorial but nothing too crazy.

Simon is awesome! He genuinely cares about his students and his work and wants to help whenever possible! The lectures could have been shorter but I enjoyed all the activities he organized! He also is very engaging and makes sure to give positive feedback to everyone!

Simon's one of the best profs at SFU. His personality is really great and makes you want to be in class. But the material in 201 is pretty boring and it's all about memorizing. His teaching style is super concise and he is an entertaining professor to say the least. I really enjoyed his lectures, but you don't really have to show up to class.

He is a nice person and very approachable. Unfortunately, he is not a great prof. He's absolutely terrible! Gives vague instructions for his assignments. He is also super picky. He takes marks off even when you follow the instructions. His lectures are super boring as he recites the textbook. You are going to fall asleep in his class.

Very strict and extremely hard marker. Very sweet lady though. Always willing to help her students even though her exams are difficult. She makes concepts relatively easy to understands but her exams are tricky.

Written assignments were marked VERY harshly for an introductory class, imo, and they want to keep the average low. Not a bad prof but I think the grading was harsh, and there weren't many opportunities to boost your grade since a huge portion of marks were from a group case report and final.

Christian is a great guy and his lectures are always fun and engaging. He is so easy to approach. His grading criteria is clear however, there is tough marking. A really good BUS 201 professor. His 3 hour lectures were not dreadful! There is a fair amount of group work. But overall Christian is an amazing person who cares for his students.

Christian is a great guy in general who knows his material very well. His lectures are always fun and engaging. However, he is a very hard marker along with his teaching assistants. The comprehensive exam had a lot of tricky multiple-choice questions. A really good BUS 201 professor, but be ready to fight for your mark as this class is curved.

Super good guy loves chatting with his students. The online class was a really fun and chill atmosphere. Not too much homework, just weekly readings of about 25 pages in the textbook and then an open book 10 question quiz to do before each lecture.
Made the class super engaging and a great environment especially for online learning. A fair marker with good feedback. Overall an amazing prof!
he has waves so 5/5
Funny guy. Very caring. Cares a lot about his students. Huge pogchamp.

Christian makes a three-hour lecture engaging and entertaining, despite mostly repeating what the textbook says. He is a tough marker, however the course is curved and can raise your grade. While he does tend to favor certain students in lectures, he emphasizes a system of fairness in his class with respect to seeking help and with grades.

Christian is an amazing person who makes a 3-hour lecture fly by with his engaging lectures. Make sure to be on top of readings and answer assignments with as much detail as possible. Yes, his marking is difficult especially for a first-year course, but this is a professor who you will learn from.

Christian is definitely a difficult marker, but if you stick to the grading rubric, you'll be just fine. I recommend getting to know him and building a relationship with him. I find that he chooses class favourites (especially in my Bus201 class), and may even treat you better depending... All in all, solid prof.

Christian is a very laid back and funny prof, however, a tough marker. The class basically just goes over reading so they're not that useful, but tutorial attendance is mandatory. He made long lectures more fun with jokes and different activities we would do in class.
Hard marker, but an excellent lecturer and teacher.

Christian is a great prof during his lectures as he makes the class really engaging even though it's 3 hours. Chapter readings are a lot and his grading scheme is sooo petty. He took off 3 marks just because someone didn't cite something properly. His tests are a lot to memorize (but that's like all 201 classes)

The course itself is intensive, but Christian made it a bit easier. Omitted the worst quiz and assignment for everyone, hints at what will be on exams. Tries to make lecture interactive and engaging. Generally a tough grader, but expectations are clear and feedback is actually helpful.
Christian is an alright professor but he can be a tough grader at times and makes you work hard for your marks. I would try to avoid him in the future.

Christian can be a tough marker but he is a very enthusiastic prof. Lectures are long but he does his best to keep the class interesting. He encourages participation in his lectures. There are online quizzes and occasional in-class assignments which are simple as long as you do the readings. However, HBR articles/quizzes can be long and boring.

Despite the 3-hour lectures and the material being mostly common sense, I found myself enjoying the course thanks to Christian. He's a very good speaker and made the material interesting; he's clear about expectations for tests and assignments. He encourages participation and doesn't shoot down students' ideas. Beware of long HBR articles though.

Alright. Let's get straight to the point. Professor V is a tough marker, but the course is a bell curve so everyone is in the same boat (which makes like no difference). He's a cool-ass dude and perhaps one of the most APPROACHABLE profs in SFU. He's not antisocial like many profs. Take your time and meet this guy! You're missing out on a bunch!

Great professor very understanding with clear cut expectations. Turns long lectures into an interactive environment so that you aren't bored out of your mind. There's weekly online quizzes and occasional in class assignments but nothing too difficult as long as you do the readings.

Christian can be a tough marker but is very nice and funny in class. His teaching style is easy going and he's shown he himself has an interest in business. His assignments are interesting and the class was engaging. The exams were fair.

Zorana is a great prof. I took 2 classes with her in my first semester at SFU and I was not disappointed. She's funny, she genuinely cares about her students, wants to help them, and hosts every lecture sleep deprived yet full of energy. You've got to take BUS 201 with her! Pray for a good group though, otherwise you're gonna have a tough time.

Dr.Z was a great teacher and great lecturer, from the few times I've been to office hours great person as well, cares about your development as a student. However, BUS 201 was her first year teaching and I am overwhelmed with the amount of reading, and small pointless assignments due each week! Constantly stressed out! Hard marking! good luck.

Avoid him if you can. He makes a business foundation course harder than it should be. He marks all the assignments and exams by himself so look out for low grades. Boring lectures, very intimidating and he doesn't even respect his audience enough to put on a mic. Overall, not a good prof choice for BUS201
Really smart guy, really passionate about the material. He does pick students at random to answer his questions, but you get used to that.
Easy class, read the text book and you'll do great but dont underestimate the final like i did

I really like him as a prof, I think you could do a lot worse than him. He expects a lot from his students, and tests are hard, but those marks can easily be made up for in assignments. He's very concise, will sometimes say a sentence in class not on the slides that will appear on an exam, so skipping class is not an option.
really arrogant, lectures are long and off topic.  Usually ends up talking about himself, HBR articles are long and pointless
Really good prof. Took 201 a required course and he was great. Intimidating in class but very approachable in his office hours. Fair exams. Really good prof.

A very intimidating prof. His lectures were fairly interesting, but all you mainly need to pass the course is the textbook. He marks quite difficulty, and you never seem to know his expectations until after you've done poorly on something. In that regards he is not a very clear teacher. Although he is knowledgeable, would not take his courses again

Did not like him as an intro to business course, very intimidating and tough. Encourages discussion but shuts down people. Important lecture, kinda interesting, but not very relevant to the textbook.  Exams are very much related to the textbook and they were between fair and hard.  If you can, take the course with another prof!!!

Good guy all around, you can tell that he genuinely likes teaching. Good use of "news", keeps material current. Textbook is mandatory, you could probably get away with a later edition, but you definitely need it for the online quizzes and in-class assignments. Midterm and Final are formatted the same - mc is easy, written is marked hard.

Love him! If you can get through him, you can get through any prof. Had him for a mandatory first year Bus course, everyone had their opinions. He's up front, it's upto you whether you can handle it or not. A lot of student engagement (as you would expect in a business class). Show up, participate and know your key terms. That's all!

Lectures was completely irrelevant from the textbook since he just talks about life. But the exams were mainly on the textbook. Remember his favorite HBR's and you will be good to go. He's not that helpful or clear on assignments. Even the TA's don't know what he wants sometimes. His class is a lot of self learning & guessing what he wants from you

Though he might sound tough at first, he really really wants to see his students succeed. His lectures are boring if you only half pay attention to them. Fully immerse yourself into his lecture and you'll find that they stuff he talks about not only helps with exam prep but applies to all aspects of life.

1 1/2 years after this course, I know that no other professor could've prepared me for university like he did. He expects a lot, but helps you achieve ambitious goals. There are 2 types of tasks: Important and urgent ones. Getting to know professors is an important one. Take initiative, visit office hours, be driven and you won't be disappointed.

He was my first business professor, and thus was my first impression of Beedie. He was more than just a lecturer; he was a figure of guidance. My friends and I felt a sense of belonging and pride for Beedie, thanks to him. Taught us material and taught us engagement alike. Great personality.

Professor Jang is what a new student really needs, despite the course being online I could feel all of her care towards every student. The lectures are long but very interesting as she elaborates with passion and knowledge. She is very passionate and will go beyond to perform a meaningful lecture. Recommend her, would take again!

She is a solid choice for a prof, she keeps the long lectures engaging and goes over important concepts well. The assignments are pretty straightforward, and in the end of the term you write an exam and complete a group project (case comp). Hope for a good team and go over article readings + lec slides to prepare for the exam.

Her lectures were engaging even though they were 3hrs long. She is super caring and gives clear criteria for assignments. I took BUS201 online with her and highly recommend! She puts you in breakout rooms almost every class, but the task is easy and straightforward.

Professor Jang is genuinely an amazing teacher and I wish I had her in person. If you read the pre readings and listen in class (although 3 hour online lectures are really hard to stay focused in), you'll do just fine on all the work. She is also extremely helpful and her or her TA's will reply to your emails about anything you need help with.

Professor Jang is the type of person that is impossible to hate. The course itself may be difficult at times, but she will make sure she is doing her best to help the class in every way possible. Her 4.9/5 rating on here is not a fluke. She deserves it

She is seriously so sweet and really wants her students to succeed. Her teaching style is very visual and will answer any question with detail. If you want to pass the comprehensive exam and do well in case comp, you must read weekly articles/textbook assigned. If you don't, you can probably get by the weekly quizzes.

Kim was a great prof! A lot of profs are just good in their respective fields and are not actually great teachers, but Kim is genuinely great at teaching. She's super kind and engaging, also very clear about content and grading.

Professor Jang was the best professor I had in my first term. She somehow made three hour lectures bearable with her great sense of humor and entertaining teaching style. The course itself isn't too hard, just make sure you're diligent with your work; especially towards the end of term. Having to juggle both the group case comp and final is hectic.

Professor Jang is a good professor she has a fun personality and does her best to make lectures engaging. I however felt that the marking was sometimes a bit too cruel for a first year, first semester course. She is picky about small details in assignments so make sure to pay attention to criteria otherwise you will lose marks.

Kimberly was an amazing prof! Super accessible outside of class and really made an effort to make the class engaging in an online environment. She is super sweet and if you have any questions at all, she will be more than happy to answer them!

Professor Jang is an AMAZING prof. She is funny and caring. Although there is a LOT of reading to do and the lectures are 3 hours long, she made it interesting. Overall you definitely should take a class with her.

Dr. Jang is the blueprint of an excellent professor. She makes lectures enjoyable, humourous and engaging, while still teaching the course content well. I cannot recommend her enough. If you are taking BUS 201, take it with Dr. Jang.

Professor Jang is such a kind and joyful soul! Although her lectures are 3 hours long, she makes them very interactive and fun - it never really feels like it's 3 hours long. Definitely a great first course into Beedie and I learned a lot!

A teacher who seriously cares for her students which I am sure has been even more challenging for her through an online setting. 3-hour lectures are tough at times but she keeps them interesting and exciting. Great teacher all around.
Very kind, explains things well. Some assignments/tests are hard, and there's a case competition which will be very stressful, but she makes sure you understand what you should be doing

Kim Jang is a legendary prof. She's super sweet, caring and a great teacher! Her lectures can be boring at times, but she is very clear with her class. She's pretty fun u have to take a class with her!

Prof: Excellent. Course: Rigorous. Readings and writing assignments every week. Participation is huge in this class, expect to talk for about 10-25 min each lecture in breakout groups. Tutorials are also heavily based on groups and participation. Exams had 64 questions and almost the entire class said it was horrible. Time was a major issue. :(

Very nice and kind prof. The 3 hour lectures are mandatory to attend and I barely paid attention to them due to how dry and boring it was. Not the profs fault though. The amount of reading and work you have to do is quite a lot. Marking is on a curve and is quite harsh. Get ready for a mandatory 7 hour case competition you must attend worth 19%.

Professor Jang is the definition of the word kind! She is so sweet and genuinely cares for all her students. She gives clear criteria and is always available for guidance if you're confused. Attendance is expected for her lectures, which she always makes more interesting, so dw about it being 3 hours. TAKE BUS201 WITH HER!!

Even though the content in the class was really dry at times, Kimberly made an effort to keep lectures as interesting and engaging as possible. She is sometimes a tough grader, but overall she seems like a great person who really cares about her students and their learning. She has an outgoing personality that made early morning lectures bearable.
She's so awesome and cool and she shows videos and stuff so it's not too boring, even though the content is dry.
Very tough grader, but gives good lectures. Overall she's good.
Honestly the best prof I've had so far at SFU
I loved him. That's all I have to say.
He's a god.

Prof. Oceguera was great, he really cared about his students and made lectures interesting. I loved his class and really recommend taking it if possible. He is a great prof but he will push you to be better by encouraging participation and giving challenging assignments. Keep up with readings, especially your HBR's. A great prof and a great person.

He is really funny and makes the three-hour-long lectures a lot more engaging than it is. Hard marker but explains concepts fairly well. Our class hyped him up all the time, he's the best. He gives life advice and cares about you as a student. Highly recommend.

Jorge genuinely cares about his students and it shows. Bus201 concepts are really dense and boring but his lectures made it seem really fun and interesting. on top of that, he teaches his students a lot of practical skills. I would definitely take another course with him, even if it wasn't for credit.
I love Jorge, such a funny and encouraging prof. Three hours can be long and he usually likes us to discuss. Class isn't too bad if you've taken business related courses in highschool.

He's a funny prof with a great sense of humor but rambles quite a bit. Gives lots of examples that directly apply to what we were learning in class. Was quite spontaneous with things like quizzes, he sometimes called them off simply because he didn't feel like giving them out. Just read and memorize the textbook, understand the HBRs and your good.

It was the first time Gord taught the course and he did a decent job. Get ready to do a lot of group projects with people you don't know. Attending lectures was only useful for the in class quiz days as he posted his lecture slides online. Main concepts from notes and quizzes were the exam questions. Prepares you well for the written part of final.

He is a very sarcastic professor who has not taught BUS 201 before. I personally thought that just studying from the textbook was good enough for his course, as he simply regurgitated what was already in the book during lectures. If possible, try to get another professor who has more experience in this course.

First time he has taught this course, however, he didn't seem to know the material too well. Tended to read off slides and go off topic and ramble on about his UBC and .com days. He marks 2/3 assignments max and doesn't give actual solid criteria or marking breakdown. Review class prior to final exam was LACKING compared to other BUS201 professors.

A solid choice. Her marking seems pretty justified & she provides feedback on most assignments. She's also extremely caring, and approachable/talkative at office hours. Lectures were dry given their three-hour length, but she does drop hints at exam material during them. Attend office hours, you may be able to raise your mark if you can justify it.
Horrible prof, makes you memorize the textbook. The class was so dry can you imagine sitting in a 3-hour lecture learning about how businesses work. The Final is worded poorly also.
She is kind but her lectures can be very long and info packed. You're definitely gonna have to work for the grade you want.

She was very friendly and relaxed online. As an intro class there wasn't too much work to do and everything was pretty straightforward but the readings were very long. Chapter and multiple article readings each week.

Anne was a fine prof. There is a chapter a week to read and be quizzed. She basically just goes over what was said in the textbook so paying attention during lectures is not necessary. But there is a participation component so you must attend. Overall nice woman.

She is super nice and very organized. Lectures are nice, she just goes over what the readings said but answers more questions. She makes the material fun and light. As for quizzes, they're pretty straight forward, nothing that the readings or lectures don't cover. Overall, I would definitely take a course of hers again.
Prof was really boring and basically just read off the slides
very unapproachable.

Very nice person, relatively boring teacher, and a wild marker. You can follow the criteria until the cows come home and still end up with a C on an assignment. Luckily the class content itself was pretty easy.
Grades based on her imagination.

Just seems like she doesn't care about being a fair marker. I've heard of numerous cases where students didn't get the marks they deserved. Overall unapprochable and her lecture slides are useless for studying. Took her last year and speaking on behalf of what I'm hearing from her this year - she seems to have gotten worse?

Susan is a kind and caring woman, she truly wants you to thrive in her class and is available for questions. However, her class is EXTREMELY DISORGANIZED. She is scattered in lectures, making them ineffective and dull. Her exams have useless content which is more memorizing based rather than testing on the actual material. Avoid her if you can.

BUS201 is a generalized course covering many topics at the surface level. Susan was an enjoyable professor, her final exam however, was puzzling (40 multiple choice based only off the textbook, yet some of those questions were never spoken about). No need to buy the textbook, just find an older version online. PARTICIPATE/ATTEND tutorial!!!!!

The exam is just memory-based, if you fail the exam, not a big deal. The case comp and assignments were okay, the lectures were extremely boring, never paid attention. There were 2 in class pop quizzes, but very easy.
Matt is a great prof - Mic drop. The final was a little bs, but a positive learning environment. Best class I had this semester.

All BUS201 classes follow the exact same material, and very similar grading structure (the final exam was the exact same thing for each professor), so the professor doesn't matter too much for this class. Martell was a good prof who explained concepts well and kept a fairly laidback lecture. 3-4 hrs of work per week. I don't regret choosing him!

I wish people told me this before taking BUS 201: there isa lot of memorizing we have to gobble up the textbook. thats just how the course is formatted not Matts fault. honestly take kim jang her exam is open book, I heard it supposed to be harder, but lets be fr its business, how hard can it get. other then that matts alright, kinda boring for 3hr

Matt has by far been my best prof so far. Super caring and wants you to succeed. Go visit him in office hours, He's super helpful and explains things very clearly. Would definitely take a class with him again.
Good prof. Takes forever to mark stuff though. Lectures are good and if you like beer this is your man

Professor Martell was a great professor for BUS 201! The lectures were engaging and they complemented the textbook material well with real-life examples and applications. I will definitely look for him in my future courses. If you follow the criteria, read through the rubrics, and put in the effort you will get a good grade. Just beat the curve ;)

Prof Martell's lectures are pretty interesting, and he does his best to engage with students. Participation matters! Asking him questions in class generates a great conversation that builds on what is taught. Some funny jokes throughout class, definitely would take again!

Not the greatest lectures, but the course was premade by the staff, and all classes used the same lectures. Answered emailed and questions usually within in 4 hours, but always expect a reply within 24 hours.  Fun prof, and a great person overall.  Lectures were three hours long, but def my favourite, sometimes boring however.

Very boring lectures. Mid term was easy (if you study) but the avg was pretty low. Final case study was super hard since we only did one practice case study throughout the whole term. HBR articles are boring. Has high expectations for projects and individual assignment so marked very hard (definitely need to put in the effort to get a decent mark).
